title: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Introduction
content: Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) is a hormone produced by the anterior pituitary in response to gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) from the hypothalamus. [1] FSH plays a role in sexual development and reproduction in both males and females.
contents: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Introduction. Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) is a hormone produced by the anterior pituitary in response to gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) from the hypothalamus. [1] FSH plays a role in sexual development and reproduction in both males and females.

title: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Issues of Concern
content: Fertility Sexual development Amenorrhea Menopause Pituitary adenomas
contents: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Issues of Concern. Fertility Sexual development Amenorrhea Menopause Pituitary adenomas

title: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Cellular Level
content: FSH is a glycoprotein dimer with alpha and beta subunits. The beta subunit is unique to FSH, while the alpha subunit is the same as in TSH, hCG, and LH. [2]
contents: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Cellular Level. FSH is a glycoprotein dimer with alpha and beta subunits. The beta subunit is unique to FSH, while the alpha subunit is the same as in TSH, hCG, and LH. [2]

title: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Cellular Level
content: GnRH stimulates FSH release. The hypothalamus produces GnRH, and it is released into the hypophyseal portal circulation to act on G-protein-coupled receptors at gonadotropic cells of the anterior pituitary. Those gonadotropic cells produce FSH and luteinizing hormone (LH) and release them into the peripheral circulation.
contents: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Cellular Level. GnRH stimulates FSH release. The hypothalamus produces GnRH, and it is released into the hypophyseal portal circulation to act on G-protein-coupled receptors at gonadotropic cells of the anterior pituitary. Those gonadotropic cells produce FSH and luteinizing hormone (LH) and release them into the peripheral circulation.

title: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Cellular Level
content: GnRH release occurs in a pulsatile manner, with low pulse frequencies stimulating more FSH production and high pulse frequencies stimulating more LH production. [1] Continuous use of GnRH suppresses the release of FSH and LH from the anterior pituitary which inhibits ovulation and estrogen production in women. Clinically, GnRH agonists like leuprolide work via this mechanism. [3]
contents: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Cellular Level. GnRH release occurs in a pulsatile manner, with low pulse frequencies stimulating more FSH production and high pulse frequencies stimulating more LH production. [1] Continuous use of GnRH suppresses the release of FSH and LH from the anterior pituitary which inhibits ovulation and estrogen production in women. Clinically, GnRH agonists like leuprolide work via this mechanism. [3]

title: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Cellular Level
content: In women, negative feedback from estrogen levels inhibits FSH secretion. [4] In men, levels of inhibin B, secreted by the Sertoli cells in response to FSH, inhibit FSH secretion via negative feedback. [5]
contents: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Cellular Level. In women, negative feedback from estrogen levels inhibits FSH secretion. [4] In men, levels of inhibin B, secreted by the Sertoli cells in response to FSH, inhibit FSH secretion via negative feedback. [5]

title: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Development
content: During fetal development, GnRH producing neurons develop from the epithelium of the medial olfactory pit and then migrate to the hypothalamus. [6] The anterior pituitary gland develops from Rathke’s pouch, a portion of the oral cavity. [2]
contents: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Development. During fetal development, GnRH producing neurons develop from the epithelium of the medial olfactory pit and then migrate to the hypothalamus. [6] The anterior pituitary gland develops from Rathke’s pouch, a portion of the oral cavity. [2]

title: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Development
content: In the second and third trimesters of pregnancy, as well during the first 3 to 6 months of infancy, the pituitary gland secretes LH and FSH. [7] LH and FSH levels peak mid-pregnancy as the first ovarian follicle or seminiferous tubule mature. [6] In males, FSH stimulates Sertoli cell proliferation, which is the most significant contributor to testicular volume in children. [7] The Sertoli cells produce an anti-mullerian hormone (AMH), which causes the involution of the Mullerian ducts, preventing the formation of female internal genitalia. [6] Clinical correlation of the early infancy LH and FSH surge:
contents: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Development. In the second and third trimesters of pregnancy, as well during the first 3 to 6 months of infancy, the pituitary gland secretes LH and FSH. [7] LH and FSH levels peak mid-pregnancy as the first ovarian follicle or seminiferous tubule mature. [6] In males, FSH stimulates Sertoli cell proliferation, which is the most significant contributor to testicular volume in children. [7] The Sertoli cells produce an anti-mullerian hormone (AMH), which causes the involution of the Mullerian ducts, preventing the formation of female internal genitalia. [6] Clinical correlation of the early infancy LH and FSH surge:

title: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Development
content: The lack of the normal infancy peak of LH and FSH might identify and diagnose infants, especially males, who have hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. Girls with monosomy Turner syndrome (45, XO) have an elevation of FSH up to 6 years old due to lack of negative feedback from nonfunctional ovaries, while girls with mosaicism (45, X/46, XX) have a much lower FSH elevation due to partial ovarian function. [6] During puberty, the hypothalamus secretes GnRH in a pulsatile manner, which stimulates the anterior pituitary to increase secretion of LH and FSH. [6]
contents: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Development. The lack of the normal infancy peak of LH and FSH might identify and diagnose infants, especially males, who have hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. Girls with monosomy Turner syndrome (45, XO) have an elevation of FSH up to 6 years old due to lack of negative feedback from nonfunctional ovaries, while girls with mosaicism (45, X/46, XX) have a much lower FSH elevation due to partial ovarian function. [6] During puberty, the hypothalamus secretes GnRH in a pulsatile manner, which stimulates the anterior pituitary to increase secretion of LH and FSH. [6]

title: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Organ Systems Involved -- Hypothalamic-Pituitary-Gonadal Axis
content: The hypothalamus secretes GnRH, which stimulates the anterior pituitary to release FSH and LH. In females, FSH receptors are located in the granulosa cells of the ovaries. In males, FSH receptors are found in the Sertoli cells of the testes. [2]
contents: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Organ Systems Involved -- Hypothalamic-Pituitary-Gonadal Axis. The hypothalamus secretes GnRH, which stimulates the anterior pituitary to release FSH and LH. In females, FSH receptors are located in the granulosa cells of the ovaries. In males, FSH receptors are found in the Sertoli cells of the testes. [2]

title: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Function -- Females
content: Estrogen production Follicular development
contents: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Function -- Females. Estrogen production Follicular development

title: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Function -- Males
content: Induction and maintenance of spermatogenesis
contents: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Function -- Males. Induction and maintenance of spermatogenesis

title: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Mechanism -- Females
content: Estrogen Production FSH stimulates granulosa cells in the ovarian follicles to synthesize aromatase, which converts androgens produced by the thecal cells to estradiol. Follicular Development and the Menstrual Cycle
contents: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Mechanism -- Females. Estrogen Production FSH stimulates granulosa cells in the ovarian follicles to synthesize aromatase, which converts androgens produced by the thecal cells to estradiol. Follicular Development and the Menstrual Cycle

title: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Mechanism -- Females
content: During the follicular phase of the menstrual cycle, FSH stimulates the maturation of ovarian follicles. As a dominant follicle takes over and secretes estradiol and inhibin, FSH secretion is suppressed. When the dominant follicle produces enough estradiol to maintain levels of 200 to 300 pg/ml for 48 hours, the hypothalamus responds with a surge of GnRH which stimulates the secretion of gonadotropic hormones instead inhibiting them. FSH peaks at the same time as the LH surge that causes ovulation. FSH then remains low throughout the luteal phase, preventing the development of new follicles. [2]
contents: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Mechanism -- Females. During the follicular phase of the menstrual cycle, FSH stimulates the maturation of ovarian follicles. As a dominant follicle takes over and secretes estradiol and inhibin, FSH secretion is suppressed. When the dominant follicle produces enough estradiol to maintain levels of 200 to 300 pg/ml for 48 hours, the hypothalamus responds with a surge of GnRH which stimulates the secretion of gonadotropic hormones instead inhibiting them. FSH peaks at the same time as the LH surge that causes ovulation. FSH then remains low throughout the luteal phase, preventing the development of new follicles. [2]

title: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Mechanism -- Males
content: FSH, along with testosterone, is necessary for maintaining normal sperm count and function. Studies have shown that FSH deprivation not only lowers sperm count but also affects the quality of the remaining sperm. [8]
contents: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Mechanism -- Males. FSH, along with testosterone, is necessary for maintaining normal sperm count and function. Studies have shown that FSH deprivation not only lowers sperm count but also affects the quality of the remaining sperm. [8]

title: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Pathophysiology
content: Elevated levels of FSH are associated with unresponsive gonads or hyperfunctioning pituitary adenomas. Low levels of FSH are associated with either hypothalamic or anterior pituitary dysfunction.
contents: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Pathophysiology. Elevated levels of FSH are associated with unresponsive gonads or hyperfunctioning pituitary adenomas. Low levels of FSH are associated with either hypothalamic or anterior pituitary dysfunction.

title: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Clinical Significance
content: FSH Levels and Male Infertility
contents: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Clinical Significance. FSH Levels and Male Infertility

title: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Clinical Significance
content: If males present with small, firm testes and azoospermia or oligospermia, elevated FSH levels can be used to differentiate Klinefelter syndrome from hypothalamic or pituitary insufficiency.  If testicular size is normal and patients present with azoospermia or oligospermia, FSH levels can be used to determine whether the cause is a primary impairment of spermatogenesis or obstructive. In an obstructive cause of infertility, FSH levels remain normal, while a primary impairment of spermatogenesis will present with elevated FSH levels. Several FSH preparations have been used to treat secondary hypogonadism in males. These preparations have been reasonably successful at inducing spermatogenesis and achieving paternity. [8]
contents: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Clinical Significance. If males present with small, firm testes and azoospermia or oligospermia, elevated FSH levels can be used to differentiate Klinefelter syndrome from hypothalamic or pituitary insufficiency.  If testicular size is normal and patients present with azoospermia or oligospermia, FSH levels can be used to determine whether the cause is a primary impairment of spermatogenesis or obstructive. In an obstructive cause of infertility, FSH levels remain normal, while a primary impairment of spermatogenesis will present with elevated FSH levels. Several FSH preparations have been used to treat secondary hypogonadism in males. These preparations have been reasonably successful at inducing spermatogenesis and achieving paternity. [8]

title: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Clinical Significance -- Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome
content: Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) is a syndrome characterized by elevated androgens, polycystic ovaries, and anovulation.  Patients with PCOS often present with hirsutism, obesity, insulin resistance, menstrual irregularity, and infertility. [9]
contents: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Clinical Significance -- Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome. Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) is a syndrome characterized by elevated androgens, polycystic ovaries, and anovulation.  Patients with PCOS often present with hirsutism, obesity, insulin resistance, menstrual irregularity, and infertility. [9]

title: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Clinical Significance -- Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome
content: In PCOS, the LH:FSH ratio is skewed due to persistently rapid GnRH pulses. These GnRH pulses lead to an increased LH: FSH ratio. This skewed ratio leads to the theca cells of the ovaries producing excess androgen while the granulosa cells do not produce enough aromatase to convert the androgens to estradiol. [1]
contents: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Clinical Significance -- Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome. In PCOS, the LH:FSH ratio is skewed due to persistently rapid GnRH pulses. These GnRH pulses lead to an increased LH: FSH ratio. This skewed ratio leads to the theca cells of the ovaries producing excess androgen while the granulosa cells do not produce enough aromatase to convert the androgens to estradiol. [1]

title: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Clinical Significance -- Hypogonadotropic Hypogonadism
content: In cases of amenorrhea with low levels of FSH and LH, the fault lies with either the hypothalamus or the pituitary gland. Stress-Induced Hypogonadotropic Hypogonadism
contents: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Clinical Significance -- Hypogonadotropic Hypogonadism. In cases of amenorrhea with low levels of FSH and LH, the fault lies with either the hypothalamus or the pituitary gland. Stress-Induced Hypogonadotropic Hypogonadism

title: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Clinical Significance -- Hypogonadotropic Hypogonadism
content: When calorie intake falls short of energy expenditure, the physiological stress decreases hypothalamic GnRH pulse frequency and amplitude, leading to low FSH and LH levels. This explains the anovulation and amenorrhea that can occur in female athletes and individuals with eating disorders due to lack of adequate caloric intake or excessive exercise. [2] [1] Kallman Syndrome
contents: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Clinical Significance -- Hypogonadotropic Hypogonadism. When calorie intake falls short of energy expenditure, the physiological stress decreases hypothalamic GnRH pulse frequency and amplitude, leading to low FSH and LH levels. This explains the anovulation and amenorrhea that can occur in female athletes and individuals with eating disorders due to lack of adequate caloric intake or excessive exercise. [2] [1] Kallman Syndrome

title: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Clinical Significance -- Hypogonadotropic Hypogonadism
content: During fetal development, GnRH producing neurons of the hypothalamus develop from the epithelium of the medial olfactory pit and then migrate to their proper place. [6] In Kallmann syndrome, a defect in this migratory process leads to the combination of anosmia and hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. [2]
contents: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Clinical Significance -- Hypogonadotropic Hypogonadism. During fetal development, GnRH producing neurons of the hypothalamus develop from the epithelium of the medial olfactory pit and then migrate to their proper place. [6] In Kallmann syndrome, a defect in this migratory process leads to the combination of anosmia and hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. [2]

title: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Clinical Significance -- Primary Ovarian Insufficiency
content: In cases of amenorrhea with elevated levels of FSH, the problem lies in the ovaries.
contents: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Clinical Significance -- Primary Ovarian Insufficiency. In cases of amenorrhea with elevated levels of FSH, the problem lies in the ovaries.

title: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Clinical Significance -- Primary Ovarian Insufficiency
content: Premature ovarian failure occurs when ovarian failure and menopause occur before age 40. When this happens, FSH levels are elevated due to the lack of negative feedback from the ovaries. Although there may be multiple genetic causes, most cases are idiopathic.
contents: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Clinical Significance -- Primary Ovarian Insufficiency. Premature ovarian failure occurs when ovarian failure and menopause occur before age 40. When this happens, FSH levels are elevated due to the lack of negative feedback from the ovaries. Although there may be multiple genetic causes, most cases are idiopathic.

title: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Clinical Significance -- Primary Ovarian Insufficiency
content: Turner Syndrome is the most common genetic disorder causing premature ovarian failure. Turner Syndrome is caused by the loss of an X chromosome (XO karyotype). Girls with Turner syndrome will present with primary amenorrhea and underdeveloped ovaries (streak ovaries) and elevated FSH levels. [10]
contents: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Clinical Significance -- Primary Ovarian Insufficiency. Turner Syndrome is the most common genetic disorder causing premature ovarian failure. Turner Syndrome is caused by the loss of an X chromosome (XO karyotype). Girls with Turner syndrome will present with primary amenorrhea and underdeveloped ovaries (streak ovaries) and elevated FSH levels. [10]

title: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Clinical Significance -- Pituitary Adenomas
content: Pituitary adenomas can develop from any of the cell types in the pituitary.  Pituitary adenomas derived from gonadotropic cells are most often nonfunctioning or function within normal hormone levels and are diagnosed due to symptoms from mass effect rather than hormone secretions. However, in sporadic, these tumors can secrete excess FSH and/or LH and can cause ovarian hyperstimulation. [11]
contents: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Clinical Significance -- Pituitary Adenomas. Pituitary adenomas can develop from any of the cell types in the pituitary.  Pituitary adenomas derived from gonadotropic cells are most often nonfunctioning or function within normal hormone levels and are diagnosed due to symptoms from mass effect rather than hormone secretions. However, in sporadic, these tumors can secrete excess FSH and/or LH and can cause ovarian hyperstimulation. [11]

title: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Clinical Significance -- Medications
content: GnRH Agonists and Antagonists
contents: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Clinical Significance -- Medications. GnRH Agonists and Antagonists

title: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Clinical Significance -- Medications
content: GnRH agonists initially stimulate secretion of LH and FSH, but when given continuously, suppress LH and FSH release. This results in ovarian suppression and decreased estrogen levels. GnRH antagonists can acutely suppress LH and FSH secretion. [2] Both GnRH agonists and antagonists have a role in the treatment of certain breast and prostate cancers, endometriosis, and uterine leiomyomas. Assisted Reproduction Techniques (ART)
contents: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Clinical Significance -- Medications. GnRH agonists initially stimulate secretion of LH and FSH, but when given continuously, suppress LH and FSH release. This results in ovarian suppression and decreased estrogen levels. GnRH antagonists can acutely suppress LH and FSH secretion. [2] Both GnRH agonists and antagonists have a role in the treatment of certain breast and prostate cancers, endometriosis, and uterine leiomyomas. Assisted Reproduction Techniques (ART)

title: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Clinical Significance -- Medications
content: Techniques such as in vitro fertilization (IVF) and intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI) help couples by using FSH to stimulate multiple follicles in the ovaries to harvest multiple eggs for fertilization. FSH is available ias urinary FSH with or without LH or recombinant FSH. [12] GnRH agonists or antagonists can be used during these cycles to prevent the LH surge and ovulation. [2]
contents: Physiology, Follicle Stimulating Hormone -- Clinical Significance -- Medications. Techniques such as in vitro fertilization (IVF) and intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI) help couples by using FSH to stimulate multiple follicles in the ovaries to harvest multiple eggs for fertilization. FSH is available ias urinary FSH with or without LH or recombinant FSH. [12] GnRH agonists or antagonists can be used during these cycles to prevent the LH surge and ovulation. [2]
